    5.3. teidata.duration.iso

    teidata.duration.iso defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using ISO 8601 standard formats
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.duration.iso = token { pattern = "[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+" }
    Example
    <time dur-iso="PT0,75H">three-quarters of an hour</time>
    Example
    <date dur-iso="P1,5D">a day and a half</date>
    Example
    <date dur-iso="P14D">a fortnight</date>
    Example
    <time dur-iso="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
    Note

    A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the last, which may have a decimal component (using either . or , as the decimal point; the latter is preferred). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first ‘time’ number-letter pair.

    For complete details, see ISO 8601 Data elements and interchange formats — Information interchange — Representation of dates and times.

    5.4. teidata.duration.w3c

    teidata.duration.w3c defines the range of attribute values available for representation of a duration in time using W3C datatypes.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="duration"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.duration.w3c = xsd:duration
    Example
    <time dur="PT45M">forty-five minutes</time>
    Example
    <date dur="P1DT12H">a day and a half</date>
    Example
    <date dur="P7D">a week</date>
    Example
    <time dur="PT0.02S">20 ms</time>
    Note

    A duration is expressed as a sequence of number-letter pairs, preceded by the letter P; the letter gives the unit and may be Y (year), M (month), D (day), H (hour), M (minute), or S (second), in that order. The numbers are all unsigned integers, except for the S number, which may have a decimal component (using . as the decimal point). If any number is 0, then that number-letter pair may be omitted. If any of the H (hour), M (minute), or S (second) number-letter pairs are present, then the separator T must precede the first ‘time’ number-letter pair.

    For complete details, see the W3C specification.

    5.5. teidata.enumerated

    teidata.enumerated defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single XML name taken from a list of documented possibilities.
    Moduletei

    5.6. teidata.language

    teidata.language defines the range of attribute values used to identify a particular combination of human language and writing system. [6.1. Language Identification]
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Element:
    • language/@ident
    • pron/@xml:lang
    • quote/@xml:lang
    Content model
    <content>
 <alternate>
  <dataRef name="language"/>
  <valList>
   <valItem ident=""/>
  </valList>
 </alternate>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.language = xsd:language | ( "" )
    Note

    The values for this attribute are language ‘tags’ as defined in BCP 47. Currently BCP 47 comprises RFC 5646 and RFC 4647; over time, other IETF documents may succeed these as the best current practice.

    A ‘language tag’, per BCP 47, is assembled from a sequence of components or subtags separated by the hyphen character (-, U+002D). The tag is made of the following subtags, in the following order. Every subtag except the first is optional. If present, each occurs only once, except the fourth and fifth components (variant and extension), which are repeatable.

    language
    The IANA-registered code for the language. This is almost always the same as the ISO 639 2-letter language code if there is one. The list of available registered language subtags can be found at http://www.iana.org/assignments/language-subtag-registry. It is recommended that this code be written in lower case.
    script
    The ISO 15924 code for the script. These codes consist of 4 letters, and it is recommended they be written with an initial capital, the other three letters in lower case. The canonical list of codes is maintained by the Unicode Consortium, and is available at http://unicode.org/iso15924/iso15924-codes.html. The IETF recommends this code be omitted unless it is necessary to make a distinction you need.
    region
    Either an ISO 3166 country code or a UN M.49 region code that is registered with IANA (not all such codes are registered, e.g. UN codes for economic groupings or codes for countries for which there is already an ISO 3166 2-letter code are not registered). The former consist of 2 letters, and it is recommended they be written in upper case; the list of codes can be searched or browsed at https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#search/code/. The latter consist of 3 digits; the list of codes can be found at http://unstats.un.org/unsd/methods/m49/m49.htm.
    variant
    An IANA-registered variation. These codes are used to indicate additional, well-recognized variations that define a language or its dialects that are not covered by other available subtags.
    extension
    An extension has the format of a single letter followed by a hyphen followed by additional subtags. These exist to allow for future extension to BCP 47, but as of this writing no such extensions are in use.
    private use
    An extension that uses the initial subtag of the single letter x (i.e., starts with x-) has no meaning except as negotiated among the parties involved. These should be used with great care, since they interfere with the interoperability that use of RFC 4646 is intended to promote. In order for a document that makes use of these subtags to be TEI-conformant, a corresponding <language> element must be present in the TEI header.

    There are two exceptions to the above format. First, there are language tags in the IANA registry that do not match the above syntax, but are present because they have been ‘grandfathered’ from previous specifications.

    Second, an entire language tag can consist of only a private use subtag. These tags start with x-, and do not need to follow any further rules established by the IETF and endorsed by these Guidelines. Like all language tags that make use of private use subtags, the language in question must be documented in a corresponding <language> element in the TEI header.

    Examples include

    sn
    Shona
    zh-TW
    Taiwanese
    zh-Hant-HK
    Chinese written in traditional script as used in Hong Kong
    en-SL
    English as spoken in Sierra Leone
    pl
    Polish
    es-MX
    Spanish as spoken in Mexico
    es-419
    Spanish as spoken in Latin America

    The W3C Internationalization Activity has published a useful introduction to BCP 47, Language tags in HTML and XML.

    5.7. teidata.name

    teidata.name defines the range of attribute values expressed as an XML Name.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Element:
    • application/@ident
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="Name"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.name = xsd:Name
    Note

    Attributes using this datatype must contain a single word which follows the rules defining a legal XML name (see http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-xml/#dt-name): for example they cannot include whitespace or begin with digits.

    5.8. teidata.numeric

    teidata.numeric defines the range of attribute values used for numeric values.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <alternate>
  <dataRef name="double"/>
  <dataRef name="token"
   restriction="(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)"/>
  <dataRef name="decimal"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.numeric =
   xsd:double | token { pattern = "(\-?[\d]+/\-?[\d]+)" } | xsd:decimal
    Note

    Any numeric value, represented as a decimal number, in floating point format, or as a ratio.

    To represent a floating point number, expressed in scientific notation, ‘E notation’, a variant of ‘exponential notation’, may be used. In this format, the value is expressed as two numbers separated by the letter E. The first number, the significand (sometimes called the mantissa) is given in decimal format, while the second is an integer. The value is obtained by multiplying the mantissa by 10 the number of times indicated by the integer. Thus the value represented in decimal notation as 1000.0 might be represented in scientific notation as 10E3.

    A value expressed as a ratio is represented by two integer values separated by a solidus (/) character. Thus, the value represented in decimal notation as 0.5 might be represented as a ratio by the string 1/2.

    5.9. teidata.outputMeasurement

    teidata.outputMeasurement defines a range of values for use in specifying the size of an object that is intended for display.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[\-+]?\d+(\.\d+)?(%|cm|mm|in|pt|pc|px|em|ex|gd|rem|vw|vh|vm)"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.outputMeasurement =
   token
   {
      pattern = "[\-+]?\d+(\.\d+)?(%|cm|mm|in|pt|pc|px|em|ex|gd|rem|vw|vh|vm)"
   }
    Example
    <figure>  <head>The TEI Logo</head>  <figDesc>Stylized yellow angle brackets with the letters <mentioned>TEI</mentioned> in    between and <mentioned>text encoding initiative</mentioned> underneath, all on a white    background.</figDesc>  <graphic height="600px" width="600px"   url="http://www.tei-c.org/logos/TEI-600.jpg"/> </figure>
    Note

    These values map directly onto the values used by XSL-FO and CSS. For definitions of the units see those specifications; at the time of this writing the most complete list is in the CSS3 working draft.

    5.10. teidata.pattern

    teidata.pattern defines attribute values which are expressed as a regular expression.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="token"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.pattern = token
    Note
    A regular expression, often called a pattern, is an expression that describes a set of strings. They are usually used to give a concise description of a set, without having to list all elements. For example, the set containing the three strings Handel, Händel, and Haendel can be described by the pattern H(ä|ae?)ndel (or alternatively, it is said that the pattern H(ä|ae?)ndel matches each of the three strings)
    Wikipedia

    This TEI datatype is mapped to the XSD token datatype, and may therefore contain any string of characters. However, it is recommended that the value used conform to the particular flavour of regular expression syntax supported by XSD Schema.

    5.11. teidata.pointer

    teidata.pointer defines the range of attribute values used to provide a single URI, absolute or relative, pointing to some other resource, either within the current document or elsewhere.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Element:
    • annotation/@target
    • change/@target
    • conversion/@fromUnit
    • conversion/@toUnit
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="anyURI"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.pointer = xsd:anyURI
    Note

    The range of syntactically valid values is defined by RFC 3986 Uniform Resource Identifier (URI): Generic Syntax. Note that the values themselves are encoded using RFC 3987 Internationalized Resource Identifiers (IRIs) mapping to URIs. For example, https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/% is encoded as https://secure.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/wiki/%25 while http://موقع.وزارة-الاتصالات.مصر/ is encoded as http://xn--4gbrim.xn----rmckbbajlc6dj7bxne2c.xn--wgbh1c/

    5.12. teidata.probCert

    teidata.probCert defines a range of attribute values which can be expressed either as a numeric probability or as a coded certainty value.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <alternate>
  <dataRef key="teidata.probability"/>
  <dataRef key="teidata.certainty"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.probCert = teidata.probability | teidata.certainty

    5.13. teidata.probability

    teidata.probability defines the range of attribute values expressing a probability.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    teidata.probCert
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="double"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.probability = xsd:double
    Note

    Probability is expressed as a real number between 0 and 1; 0 representing certainly false and 1 representing certainly true.

    5.14. teidata.replacement

 <textNode/>
</content>

    5.15. teidata.sex

    teidata.sex defines the range of attribute values used to identify human or animal sex.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Element:
    • person/@sex
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef key="teidata.word"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.sex = teidata.word
    Note

    Values for attributes using this datatype may be locally defined by a project, or may refer to an external standard, such as vCard's sex property http://microformats.org/wiki/gender-formats (in which M indicates male, F female, O other, N none or not applicable, U unknown), or the often used ISO 5218:2004 Representation of Human Sexes http://standards.iso.org/ittf/PubliclyAvailableStandards/c036266_ISO_IEC_5218_2004(E_F).zip (in which 0 indicates unknown; 1 male; 2 female; and 9 not applicable, although the ISO standard is widely considered inadequate); cf. CETH's Recommendations for Inclusive Data Collection of Trans People http://transhealth.ucsf.edu/trans?page=lib-data-collection.

    5.16. teidata.temporal.iso

    teidata.temporal.iso defines the range of attribute values expressing a temporal expression such as a date, a time, or a combination of them, that conform to the international standard Data elements and interchange formats – Information interchange – Representation of dates and times.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <alternate>
  <dataRef name="date"/>
  <dataRef name="gYear"/>
  <dataRef name="gMonth"/>
  <dataRef name="gDay"/>
  <dataRef name="gYearMonth"/>
  <dataRef name="gMonthDay"/>
  <dataRef name="time"/>
  <dataRef name="dateTime"/>
  <dataRef name="token"
   restriction="[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.temporal.iso =
   xsd:date
 | xsd:gYear
 | xsd:gMonth
 | xsd:gDay
 | xsd:gYearMonth
 | xsd:gMonthDay
 | xsd:time
 | xsd:dateTime
 | token { pattern = "[0-9.,DHMPRSTWYZ/:+\-]+" }
    Note

    If it is likely that the value used is to be compared with another, then a time zone indicator should always be included, and only the dateTime representation should be used.

    For all representations for which ISO 8601 describes both a basic and an extended format, these Guidelines recommend use of the extended format.

    While ISO 8601 permits the use of both 00:00 and 24:00 to represent midnight, these Guidelines strongly recommend against the use of 24:00.

   xsd:date
 | xsd:gYear
 | xsd:gMonth

    Note

    If it is likely that the value used is to be compared with another, then a time zone indicator should always be included, and only the dateTime representation should be used.

    5.18. teidata.text

    teidata.text defines the range of attribute values used to express some kind of identifying string as a single sequence of Unicode characters possibly including whitespace.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="string"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.text = string
    Note

    Attributes using this datatype must contain a single ‘token’ in which whitespace and other punctuation characters are permitted.

    5.19. teidata.truthValue

    teidata.truthValue defines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Element:
    • listChange/@ordered
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="boolean"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.truthValue = xsd:boolean
    Note

    The possible values of this datatype are 1 or true, or 0 or false.

    This datatype applies only for cases where uncertainty is inappropriate; if the attribute concerned may have a value other than true or false, e.g. unknown, or inapplicable, it should have the extended version of this datatype: teidata.xTruthValue.

    5.20. teidata.version

    teidata.version defines the range of attribute values which may be used to specify a TEI or Unicode version number.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Element:
    • TEI/@version
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.version = token { pattern = "[\d]+(\.[\d]+){0,2}" }
    Note

    The value of this attribute follows the pattern specified by the Unicode consortium for its version number (http://unicode.org/versions/). A version number contains digits and fullstop characters only. The first number supplied identifies the major version number. A second and third number, for minor and sub-minor version numbers, may also be supplied.

    5.21. teidata.versionNumber

    teidata.versionNumber defines the range of attribute values used for version numbers.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Element:
    • application/@version
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*(\.[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*){0,3}"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.versionNumber =
   token { pattern = "[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*(\.[\d]+[a-z]*[\d]*){0,3}" }

    5.22. teidata.word

    teidata.word defines the range of attribute values expressed as a single word or token.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    teidata.enumerated teidata.sex
    Content model
    <content>
 <dataRef name="token"
  restriction="[^\p{C}\p{Z}]+"/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.word = token { pattern = "[^\p{C}\p{Z}]+" }
    Note

    Attributes using this datatype must contain a single ‘word’ which contains only letters, digits, punctuation characters, or symbols: thus it cannot include whitespace.

    5.23. teidata.xTruthValue

    teidata.xTruthValue (extended truth value) defines the range of attribute values used to express a truth value which may be unknown.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <alternate>
  <dataRef name="boolean"/>
  <valList>
   <valItem ident="unknown"/>
   <valItem ident="inapplicable"/>
  </valList>
 </alternate>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.xTruthValue = xsd:boolean | ( "unknown" | "inapplicable" )
    Note

    In cases where where uncertainty is inappropriate, use the datatype teidata.TruthValue.

    5.24. teidata.xpath

    teidata.xpath defines attribute values which contain an XPath expression.
    Moduletei
    Used by
    Content model
    <content>
 <textNode/>
</content>
    Declaration
    tei_teidata.xpath = text
    Note

    Any XPath expression using the syntax defined in [[undefined XSLT2]].

    When writing programs that evaluate XPath expressions, programmers should be mindful of the possibility of malicious code injection attacks. For further information about XPath injection attacks, see the article at OWASP.

    6. Lemma-Informationen

    6.1.

    Basic lemma forms and grammatical information

    The top of every article is the lemma, which is followed on the next line by its grammatical information:
    feiern
     Verb (schwach)
    Sample TEI encoding of a verb as follows:
    <form type="lemma">  <orth>feiern</orth> </form> <gramGrp>  <gram type="pos">Verb</gram>  <iType>schwach</iType> </gramGrp>
    Formatting Rules:
    • Where 2 instances of //gramGrp/gram[@type='pos']; print comma "," and "auch" after
    • For lemma variants; where 2 instances of any category of //gramGrp/gram[@type];
      print:
      • UNIQUE VALUES separated by comma ","
      • "und" before final instance (All should be in round brackets as per other pre-established rules)
    • The lemma will be rendered in bold. The grammatical info in normal text on the next line.

    Note: Editors need not tag grammatical content that will not be printed in the text; e.g. if generally nouns are only implicitly specified by the explicit inclusion of the gender, thus tagging the gender as in the following example is enough (as we can actually automatically add it later in an attribute):
    <gramGrp>  <gram type="gender">Fem.</gram> </gramGrp>

    6.2. Variant lemma forms
    Lemmavarianten


    For as many variant forms of a lemma there are, they can be listed immediately following the main lemma:
    feiern, gefeiern
     Verb (schwach)
    This is encoded in TEI identically as the main lemma in sequence as follows:
    <form type="lemma">  <orth>feiern</orth> </form> <form type="lemma">  <orth>gefeiern</orth> </form> <gramGrp>  <gram type="pos">Verb</gram>  <iType>schwach</iType> </gramGrp>
    Formatting Rules:
    • These will be separated in redition schema by commas.
    • Where form @type + gram printed, e.g. "(kurzform, Neutrum)" do not print the value of @subtype when is is "movierung"

    6.3. Verbreitung

    <usg type="verbreitung">  <placeName type="grossregion">mSTir.</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">öSTir.</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">OTir.</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">NTir.</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">Ktn.</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">Stmk.</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">Pinzg.</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">OÖ</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">NÖ</placeName>  <placeName type="grossregion">Bgl.</placeName> </usg>
    Formatting Rules:
    • Print subheader: "Verbreitung": before //entry/usg[@type = "verbreitung"]
    • Insert semicolon ";" between each: //placeName[@type="grossregion"]

    6.4. Lautung

    This section contains an overview of certain relevant issues in the phonological features found in the given dialectal varieties with normalized forms as examples.
     Lautung
     Überblick: Wie bei allen Wörtern mit auf mhd. iu zurückgehenden Stammvokal zeigt sich hohe areale Variation, die nur teilweise auch diachrone Zustände
     widerspiegelt. So finden sich noch konservative eo-Dipthonge im Mbair. (ϕēȯrɒtßn̥), ansonsten dominieren (auch im Mbair.) ui-Diphthonge
     (ϕuirėtßn) und daraus entstandene jüngere Formen wie Diphthonge mit gesenktem Onset (ϕōɩ̨̮rėtßn), Diphthonge mit entrundetem Onset (ϕä́̄įrḙτσn̥) und sogar
     a-Monophthonge (fɒrǝtsn̥). Das Intensivierungssuffix -etzen erscheint teilweise mit a-haltigem Anlaut, manchmal ist mit dem Suffix ein
     l-Einschub bei gleichzeitigem Schwund von r verbunden (foiladsn). Anlautendes f tritt teilweise lenisiert auf
     (ϕuirėtßn).
    This is encoded in the TEI as follows:
    <note type="überblick">Wie bei allen Wörtern mit auf mhd. <c>iu</c> zurückgehenden Stammvokal zeigt sich hohe areale Variation, die nur teilweise auch diachrone Zustände widerspiegelt. So finden sich noch konservative <c>eo</c>-Dipthonge im Mbair. (<c>ϕēȯrɒtßn̥</c>), ansonsten dominieren (auch im Mbair.) <c>ui</c>-Diphthonge (<c>ϕuirėtßn</c>) und daraus entstandene jüngere Formen wie Diphthonge mit gesenktem Onset (<c>ϕōɩ̨̮rėtßn</c>), Diphthonge mit entrundetem Onset (<c>ϕä́̄įrḙτσn̥</c>) und sogar <c>a</c>-Monophthonge (<c>fɒrǝtsn̥</c>). Das Intensivierungssuffix -etzen erscheint teilweise mit <c>a</c>-haltigem Anlaut, manchmal ist mit dem Suffix ein <c>l</c>-Einschub bei gleichzeitigem Schwund von <c>r</c> verbunden ( <c>foiladsn</c>.) Anlautendes <c>f</c> tritt teilweise lenisiert auf (<c>ϕuirėtßn</c>). </note>
    Formatting Rules:
    • Print subheader: "Überblick"
    • Print contents of //note/xr/ref in italics
    • Wrap contents of //note/xr/ref in round brackets (same as rule for wrapping placenames)
    • Print contents of //note/c in italics

    7. Belegauswahl
    Dialect listing section

    The Belegauswahl section contains dialectal information, specifically:
    • Geographic information from where the forms were collected;
    • Phonetic forms in Teutonista notation;
    • Grammatical information (suplimentary to that specified in lemma) Note: (Note: that grammatical information is only occasionally included);
    Belegauswahl
     ϕuirėtßn (Hallein, Tenneng.); ϕēȯrɒtßn̥ (Hausrv.), ϕōɩ̨̮rėtßn (Bad Ischl, Traunv.); ϕä́̄įrḙτσn̥ (Bad Großpertholz, Waldv.), foiladsn (Allentsteig, Waldv.); fɒrǝtsn̥ (Pilgersdorf, MBgl.)
    The geographic information is given before the dialect forms which have been observed/collected from somewhere in that region.All dialect forms are wrapped in a larger <form> element with the type=belegauswahlThis is encoded in the TEI as follows:
    <form type="belegauswahl">  <form type="dialect">   <pron xml:lang="bar-AT">ϕuirėtßn</pron>   <usg type="geo">    <placeName>Hallein</placeName>    <placeName type="region">Tenneng.</placeName>   </usg>  </form>  <form type="dialect">   <pron xml:lang="bar-AT">ϕēȯrɒtßn̥</pron>   <usg type="geo">    <placeName type="region">Hausrv.</placeName>   </usg>  </form>  <form type="dialect">   <pron xml:lang="bar-AT">Fadīkeit</pron>   <usg type="geo">    <placeName>ϕōɩ̨̮rėtßn</placeName>    <placeName type="region">Traunv.</placeName>   </usg>  </form>  <form type="dialect">   <pron xml:lang="bar-AT">ϕä́̄įrḙτσn̥</pron>   <usg type="geo">    <placeName>Bad Großpertholz</placeName>    <placeName type="region">Waldv.</placeName>   </usg>  </form> </form>
    Dialect forms can have grammatical content and/or additional form content such as "diminutive". These each have their own rules for formatting
    <form type="dialect">  <pron xml:lang="bar-AT"/>  <gramGrp>   <gram type="number"/>  </gramGrp>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName/>   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg> </form>
    Formatting Rules:
    • Print: "Belegauswahl": before //form[@type = "belegauswahl"]
    • Render: //pron in italics
    • Insert: semicolon after //form/usg[@type="geo"] //form[@type="dialect"]and ...
    • Print: brackets "(" ")" around //entry/form/usg[@type="geo"]
    • If //form[@type="dialect] contains //gram Print value in square brackets "[Pl.]"
    • If 2..n consecutive //entry/form with the same //geo and //gram value: Print as one at the end of the second: e.g. 
      "fårfln und fårfln [Pl.] (Fusch an der Großglocknerstraße, Pinzg.)"
    • If 2..n consecutive //entry/form/usg[@type="geo"] contain the same geo information:
      • Insert: "und" between //form(i) and //form(i+1)
      • Print: //geo values in brackets following the last //form[@type="dialect"] with the same value


    7.1. Encoding specifics for geographic information for dialect forms

    .............
    <form type="dialect">  <pron xml:lang="bar-AT">fákktišš</pron>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName>Herzogenburg</placeName>   <placeName type="grossregion">Mostv.</placeName>  </usg> </form> <form type="dialect">  <pron xml:lang="bar-AT">fáktiš</pron>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion">Wien</placeName>  </usg> </form>
    ,..............

    7.2. Encoding specifics for grammatical information for dialect forms

    If the dialect form has grammatical information associated with it, the <gramGrp> (and subsequent tags) should be included inside the <form>
    <form type="dialect">  <pron xml:lang="bar-AT">fairɐt</pron>  <gramGrp>   <gram>P1</gram>  </gramGrp> </form>
    Formatting Rules
    • Brackets should not be included in the gram info directly. They can be added with rendering
    • surround content of //form[@type="variant" and @xml:lang="bar-AT"]/gramGrp/gram with brackets

    8.

    KommentarComment on issues such as pronunciation of full or partial content in one or more dialect varieties, also contains references to normalized dialect forms presented in Belegauswahl/Lautung. References to single phones are encoded as <c>; references to dialect or lemma forms are represented as <xr>; where reference to normalized dialect form, the value of <ref>type will be normalized
    <note type="kommentar">Die Intensität des <c>k</c>-Lautes sowie dessen Behauchung unterliegen im gesamten Untersuchungsgebiet Schwankungen, wobei Lenisvarianten eher im Mbair. zu finden sind (<xr>   <ref type="normalized">fabrikla</ref>  </xr>). </note>
    Formatting Rules:
    • wrap contents of //note/xr/ref in round brackets (same as rule for wrapping placenames)
    • print contents of //note/xr/ref in italics
    • print contents of //note/c in italics

    9.

    EtymologieTypically an etymology section has: one or more etymons, labels for the language of the etymon, possibly labels relating to the process, a definition of the etymon and a bibliographic reference.
    The tags and contents are as follows:
    • <etym> (etymology) highest level element in which all etymological descriptions must occur. Automatically part of article template. Contains as children:
      • <cit> type="etymon"
      • <desc> (description): contains prose description of etymon or general information about the etymology.
      • <lbl> (label): contains a label pertaining to the etymon or its process that is systematically re-used throughout the data. .. Note: Need to decide whether to just use <desc>.
      • <bibl> (bibliography): contains bibliographic information pertaining to the etymology in general (all forms). If bibliography is for only a single etymon, then it should be placed in <cit> type="etymon"
    • <cit> type="etymon" (etymon) contains everything pertaining to the etymon specifically: <lang>, <lang>, <date>, <form>, <def> Contains as children:
      • <lang> contains the language of the etymon
      • <date> contains the date (specific or general) of the etymon's first observed or typical timeframe of usage
      • <form> contains the form of the etymon, generally <orth>
      • <gramGrp> (including children grammatical tags): <gram>, <iType>) contains grammatical information pertaining to the etymon form.
      • <def> contains the definition of an etymon (if more than one, can occur in sequence, need rule to add numbering)
    Note: Need to come up with contingency on how to deal with where there may be: i) variants of the etymon; ii) where there may be more than one sense of the etymon
    Below is an example of a typical etymon encoded in TEI:
    <cit type="etymon">  <lang>fnhd.</lang>  <form>   <orth>fatzen</orth>  </form>  <def>spotten, Zum Narren halten</def> </cit>
    Below is an example of two etymons from different language stages (Althochdeutsch and Mittelhochdeutsch), and the second one has variants:
    <etym>  <cit type="etymon">   <lang>ahd.</lang>   <form>    <orth>fratôn</orth>   </form>  </cit>  <cit type="etymon">   <lang>mhd.</lang>   <form>    <orth>vreten</orth>   </form>   <form>    <orth>vraten</orth>   </form>   <form>    <orth>vretten</orth>   </form>   <def>entzünden; wund reiben</def>  </cit> </etym>
    This should be rendered as follows:
    ahd. fratôn; mhd. vreten, vraten, vretten 'entzünden; wund reiben'
    Formatting Rules
    • print "Etymologie" before etym
    • enter comma after cit where //cit followed by //seg[@type="desc"]
    • value of (etymon form) : //cit[@type="etymon]/form/orth in italics
    • add semi-colon between two consecutive instances of //cit[@type="etymon]
    • surround: contents of //def[not(@type)] with single quotes (both in sense and in etymology)
    • surround: //ref[@type='bibl'] contents with brackets "(" ")"
    • add colon betweeen: //etym/bibl/date (or /edition) and //etym/bibl/citedRange
    • add semi-colon after //seg[@type='desc' and @part='F']:
    • add comma between two consective instance of //form/orth in a single //cit[@type="etymon]
    Note: <bibl> goes as child of <etym> (unless the <bibl> is specifically for the etymon)
    <etym>  <cit type="etymon">   <lang>mhd.</lang>   <form type="variant">    <orth>vreten</orth> <!-- might consider changing etymon structure according to eventual TEI Lex-0 recommendations -->   </form>   <form type="variant">    <orth>vretten</orth>   </form>   <form type="variant">    <orth>vraten</orth>   </form>   <def>entzünden; wundreiben; herumziehen; quälen; plagen</def>  </cit>  <ref type="bibl">vgl. <title>LEXER</title>   <date>1878</date>   <edition>III</edition>   <citedRange>502</citedRange>  </ref> </etym>

    9.1. Discontinuous description text

    In certain cases an etymology may start a prose description and within the text include an etymon form creating a fragmented description. In these cases use the <seg> element with the attribute part, the values of which may be one of the following:
    • "I"(capital "i") for (initial) this is the initial part of a fragmented element;
    • "M(medial) this is a medial part of a fragmented element;
    • "F(final) this is the final part of a fragmented element;
    seit dem 18. Jh. belegt, auf fickfacken 'hin- und herlaufen' zurückgeführt; evtl. auch auf fnhd. fatzen 'spotten, zum Narren halten' zurückführbar (vgl. PFEIFER 2014: 329)
    <etym>  <date>seit dem 18. Jh.</date>  <seg type="desc" part="I">belegt, auf</seg>  <cit type="etymon">   <form>    <orth>fickfacken</orth>   </form>   <def>hin- und herlaufen</def>  </cit>  <seg type="desc" part="M">zurückgeführ evtl. auch auf</seg>  <cit type="etymon">   <lang>fnhd.</lang>   <form>    <orth>fatzen</orth>   </form>   <def>spotten, Zum Narren halten</def>  </cit>  <seg type="desc" part="F">zurückführbar</seg>  <ref type="bibl">   <title>Pfeifer</title>   <date>2014</date>   <citedRange>329</citedRange>  </ref> </etym>
    Note: could enhance with attribute-value @notBefore="1800"
    Note: <bibl> goes as child of <etym> (unless the bibl is specifically for the etymon)

    10. Bedeutung
    Formatting Rules:
    • Print "Bedeutung" (project should only have one or the other!)
    • where (2...n) //sense for each print number in roman numerals with period
    • where (2...n) //def 's in //sense before each print number in arabic numerals with period
    • surround contents of //def[not(@type='umschreibung')] with single quotes (both in //sense and in //etym)
    • letter spacing within def should be 1 pt
    • //cit[@type="example"]/quote in italics
    • surround //cit[@type="example"]/usg[@type="geo"] contents with brackets "(" ")"
    • add a long dash before each //cit[@type="example"]
    An example of a typed "umschreibung" definition:
    <sense>  <def type="umschreibung">Beschreibung für ein Schaf, dessen Nieren sich durch einen Fall oder Stoß gelöst haben</def> .... </sense>

    10.1. Cross-referencing variant forms in Bedeutung:

    Where a sense corresponds to one or more specific variant forms of the lemma, it is written as follows:
    This is encoded in the TEI structure as follows:
    <sense>  <lbl>auch</lbl>  <xr type="variant" subtype="diminutive">   <ref>Farferl</ref>  </xr>  <xr type="variant" subtype="diminutive">   <ref>Färferl</ref>  </xr>  <xr type="variant" subtype="diminutive">   <ref>Färfellein</ref>  </xr>  <def>Mehl- bzw. Teigkügelchen, meist als Suppeneinlage verwendet</def>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <cit type="example">   <quote xml:lang="bar-AT"/>   <usg type="geo">    <placeName/>    <placeName type="grossregion"/>   </usg>  </cit> </sense>
    Note:

    11. Wortbildung
    Formatting Rules
    • before variant in Wortbildung surround form with brackets and print 'auch' before form
    • insert "Wortbildung" before first //re (same label for: compound, derivations, suffixes
    • //cit[@type="example"]/quote in italics
    • surround //cit[@type="example"]/usg[@type="geo"] contents with brackets "(" ")"
    • add a long dash before each //cit[@type="example"]
    • //re/form/orth in italics
    • surround contents of //def[not(@type='umschreibung')] with single quotes (both in //sense and in //etym)
    <re>  <form type="lemma" subtype="compound">   <orth/>  </form>  <sense>   <def/>  </sense>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <cit type="example">   <quote xml:lang="bar-AT"/>   <usg type="geo">    <placeName/>    <placeName type="grossregion"/>   </usg>  </cit> </re>
    Note:

    12. Redewendung
    Formatting Rules
    • Before variant in Wortbildung:
      • surround form with brackets
      • Print 'auch' before //form
      • Print "Redenwendung" before first //form[@type='MWE']
    <re type="redewendung">  <xr>   <ref/>  </xr>  <form type="lemma" subtype="MWE">   <orth/>  </form>  <sense>   <def/>  </sense>  <usg type="geo">   <placeName type="grossregion"/>  </usg>  <cit type="example">   <quote xml:lang="bar-AT"/>   <usg type="geo">    <placeName/>    <placeName type="grossregion"/>   </usg>  </cit> </re>
    Note:

    12.1.

    Redenwendungen can have embedded <re> when all the MWE's correspond to a given variant form of the lemma. In such cases, the head of the first <re> is a cross-reference for corresponding to the given variant of the lemma, eg.:
    <re type="redewendung">  <xr type="variant">   <ref>Fäckel</ref>  </xr>  <re>   <form type="MWE">    <orth xml:lang="bar-AT">Kinder und Fäckel haben alleweil leere Säckel</orth>   </form>    ...  </re> ... </re>

    13. Bibliographies

    Bibliographic information can be placed within the <sense> or <etym> sections. The formatting of bibliographic citations throughout articles which are most basically encoded as <ref> elements with the attribute-value: type="bibl". Within this element, the child elements <lbl>, <citedRange> and <date> may occur. ....
    <ref type="bibl">  <lbl>vgl.</lbl> <!-- AUTHOR -->( <!-- YYYY -->: <citedRange>315</citedRange>) </ref>
    Non-literary citations such as: personal communications, and online sources can also be made. These are expressed in the TEI as different values of subtype; e.g. either "personal" or "online"
    <ref type="bibl" subtype="personal">  <persName>Jakob Ebner</persName>  <lbl>persönlich</lbl>  <date type="accessed">18.02.2019</date> </ref>
    or
    <ref type="bibl" subtype="online"> <!-- AUTHOR DATE --> <!-- ONLINE? -->  <xr>   <ref target="http://www.urlhere.org/Example">form</ref>   <date type="accessed"/>  </xr> </ref>
    Where TEI structure is the following:
    <ref type="bibl" subtype="personal">  <persName>Jakob Ebner</persName>  <lbl>persönlich</lbl>  <date type="accessed">18.02.2019</date> </ref>
    The date portion should be rendered as follows:
    [19.02.2019]
    Where there are multiple bibliographic citations,
    <ref type="bibl"> <!-- AUTHOR INSERTED HERE -->  <date> <!-- DATE INSERTED HERE -->  </date> </ref> <ref type="bibl"> <!-- AUTHOR INSERTED HERE -->  <date> <!-- DATE INSERTED HERE -->  </date> </ref> <ref type="bibl"> <!-- AUTHOR INSERTED HERE -->  <date> <!-- DATE INSERTED HERE -->  </date> </ref>
    Thus the output should be rendered as follows:
    [AUTHOR YYYY; AUTHOR YYYY; AUTHOR YYYY]
    Thus what is in the source TEI as:
    <ref type="bibl">AUTHOR <date>2001</date> </ref> <ref type="bibl">LEXER <date>2000</date> </ref> <ref type="bibl">LEXER <date>2001</date> </ref>
    Should be printed as:
    [AUTHOR 2001; LEXER 2000, 2001]
    In cases in the Bedeutung (TEI <sense>) which contain an example sentence which is cited from a source, the citation may also include
    Formatting Rules:
    • If more than 1 //ref[@type="bibl"] occur in sequence, wrap all in square brackets, e.g. "[" preceeding the first, "]" following the last.
    • If more than 1 //ref[@type="bibl"] occur in sequence, separate each with semicolon, e.g. ";"
    • Insert comma after last content before //date in //ref[@type='bibl']
    • Print: square brackets "[" "]" around //date[@type="accessed"]
    • If in more than 1 //ref[@type="bibl"] occur in sequence, one author is cited for multiple works, only print name once and separate date by comma
